column107: Exploring user agent strings passed by web browsers could be interesting.  Some will be known bad, others will be valid but forbidden by policy, others may change frequently over time and be indicative of a covert channel.  As a use case it might be interesting to see how malware conducts command and control via purported web browsing.
column108: This gets into the realm of analytics but combining file sharing data with human resources data (say of a person who is likely to be fired) might be interesting.
column109: Social media sentiment analysis tools may be helpful here.
column110: I see visualization as a useful interface between the human and the machine.  To me, the most interesting scenarios are when visualizations enable humans to find important things that machines can't, but then can enable the human to properly parameterize the insight so that the machine can do the heavy lifting in the future.  This frees up the human to take on a new challenge the machine cannot yet handle.  Then the cycle continues.  This is the only approach that is scalable.

column107: We use the IPS features of the firewall. Also the BotNetworks can be seen, but we are not analysing the for example user agent or the time user opens a page and visit per session.
